Stanley Cup

Description: The most revered trophy in all of sports, the Stanley Cup is awarded annually to the National Hockey League champion. Also the oldest trophy in North American professional sports, the Stanley Cup has changed in size and shape over the years. The current version of the trophy is made of silver and nickel alloy, is almost 3 feet tall and weighs nearly 35 pounds.

Learn More: Fans around the world now can celebrate and explore the Stanley Cup like never before via a digital replica of the trophy as well as an augmented reality experience, both available at NHL.com/StanleyCupAR.

2021-22 Winner: The Colorado Avalanche dethroned the two-time defending champion Tampa Bay Lightning in six games in the Final to win the Stanley Cup for the third time in franchise history (also 1995-96 and 2000-01). Colorado claimed its championship by going 16-4 in the playoffs, becoming the sixth team since 1987 (when all four rounds went to the best-of-seven format) to capture the Stanley Cup with four or fewer postseason losses. Overall, the Avalanche – who set franchise records for wins (56) and points (119) during the regular season – posted 72 combined victories in 2021-22, tied for the most in a single season in NHL history (w/ 1976-77 MTL, 1983-84 EDM and 1995-96 DET). Colorado concluded the postseason with a 9-1 record as visitors, one shy of the League benchmark for road wins in a playoff year, and became the fourth Stanley Cup champions in NHL history to earn each of its four series-clinching victories on the road (also 2007-08 DET, 2008-09 PIT and 2017-18 WSH). Ten of the Avalanche’s playoff wins (including all four series-clinchers) were achieved in comeback fashion, tied with the 2008-09 Pittsburgh Penguins for the most in a single postseason.
